text: Mets owners have reached a settlement in

reporting for business day live i'll be

the next blockbuster but first we've an

now is Peter lattman from DealBook hello
Peter hey Winnie so the Wilpon the
owners of the Mets have been battling
with the trustee in the Madoff case over
giving some of the money back that had
come out of the Madoff investments and
they were set to go to trial what's
happened this morning so it's pretty
dramatic news and at the same time
anti-climactic news because they were
supposed to go to trial this morning and
they literally settled on the courthouse
steps the two sides have agreed to a
settlement and what's going to happen is
the Mets owners the will ponds and the
katzes are going to pay the Madoff
trustee 162 million dollars which is
right down the middle of the amount that
they could have paid which was as much
as 350 million dollars and on the low
end they were already on the hook for
about 80 million dollars so what was the
incentive for the trustee Picard to do
this instead of going to trial well it
was a complicated case and look in some
ways there's no ties in baseball but I
think the way to characterize this is
it's sort of a tie um they've been
battling for the last year's you've said
accusing the will pawns of being
willfully blind to all the red flags
that the madoff fraud had essentially
being complicit in the fraud but it was
a real risk to bring this case to trial
because if they got a negative ruling
and didn't prove their case it could
have hurt all of their other cases that
they have against much bigger fish like
the banks like JPMorgan so if they got a
negative ruling it could have heard so
in a sense this is better for them
because it doesn't risk as much some of
the other cases that were out there they
don't have to worry about a bad
precedent that's right and look this
would have been the first case that
would have gone to trial it was unclear
how a jury would have ruled and on the
other side the Mets really didn't want
to
more weeks of bad publicity right this
has been an ugly battle and the trial
would have been you know daily coverage
with big headlines and after all they've
got spring training down in Florida so
they've got other things on their mind
so what does this mean for the
financially strapped mats they were
already struggling where they going to
get the money well they say that the
money is going to come from the fact
that they were net losers in the Madoff
scheme meaning they put more money in
and they got out so they can get that

and it hopefully won't affect the Mets

and this certainly isn't great news for

under Steve Jobs Apple was sitting under
100 billion dollars in cash and yet had
resisted this what's changed here well
that's right as of December they had
nearly a hundred billion and there was
mounting pressure from Wall Street for
them to do something because they were
earning so little interest on that cash
but you know eventually they just
capitulated to investors and the idea
well you know we have to put some of
this money to work so they issued a 265
dividend they'll be coming down later
this year and that's paid quarterly to
investors yes you know Senate on top of
that they will have a 10 billion dollar

announcements will equal about 45
billion over the next three years so it
is quite a large sum of money but at the
same time Apple is still generating a
lot of cash they added more than 30
billion dollars last year in cash and as
they say their ipad sales are very

on Wall Street expect them to just
generate more and more cash over the
next few years so so where did we go
from here when Microsoft for example
started paying a dividend people said
it's a mature company it's no longer a
big growth company should we have those
kind of concerns about Apple you know I
don't think analysts are saying the

that when you look at the sales growth
of all those products and how they
continue to make such high margins the
expectation is that Apple is actually
quite a fast growing company though may
be considered
when you consider how many years it's

continue to manage investors interest
and they said on the call today that
they did this also to attract new

know we can't justify having apple on

diffident and the stock has run up so

but a lot more cash abroad what did they
say about that yeah what's significant
about these announces that they're
drawing from their domestic cash pile
and cook and executives said that Apple
is not drawing from their international

and that would involve so they're hoping
that Washington will eventually change

some of this cash back from abroad but
in the meantime what they said is we're
going to use our domestic cash pile and
we'll still have enough to do some
strategic options maybe some
acquisitions as they have in the past
thanks so much for joining us today
Evelyn thank you now we've got Larry

morning Larry how are you good so let's
talk about investors in dividend stocks
investors looking for yield have really

about what companies are going to be
doing in the future I'd say no I think
apple is a special case I mean it's true
you know we're now a few ways a few
years away from the recession the banks
obviously are better capitalized they're
starting so JP Morgan last week
announced a dividend so that's part of a

unique position having had a lot of cash
on its balance sheet for many years and
not delivering a dividend and after a
lot of clamoring from investors finally
delivering one and I think also there it
will appeal to a different class of
investors who do look at stocks that pay

side of the coin though is the question
whether the signals that they're not
going to be reinvesting it as much in

many new products on you know in
in the future so I think it's a balance
thing I think that net is probably not
going to do very much so tech stocks
have been really on a rear on a roar
here Apple was one of many you know can

that we sort of have the European debt

if not taken care of what sort of your

mean last six to nine months the two
issues that have really weighed on the
market is one concerns about global
growth and the possibility of a

the European debt crisis and both of
them look a lot better today than they

looks like to us is that there's been
actually very narrow participation in
this rally you see it in very low

and have been on the sidelines and that

not as fast as I start this year as we
would like coming out of such a deep

rest of the year yeah I think the u.s.
is on a solid but not spectacular growth
track I think before the u.s. gets to a
normal recovery you've got to see
single-family housing recovering and
it's not multifamily has recovered but
not single family housing it's unlikely
to do so before the election so that
will kick in at some point but it's not
kicking in yet so I think you're
probably looking at a US economy that's
going to trend in the two to
two-and-a-half percent range but the
labor market should continue to grow and
I think it's a solid recovery but not a
very fast growing recovery so Bernanke
the Fed Chairman he sort of put a little
damper recently in his remarks saying
that maybe the jobs had improved faster
than the economy do you think the
economy is going to pick up enough to

it make taper off a little bit but i
think the labor market is following the
I think that it's true i think what

all right who knows maybe they'll revise

clearly improved I think going forward
to think to watch is probably energy

we're shifting our attentions thanks so

a lord of the rings for a new generation
happy Hunger Games the marketing

is to create some sort of world that can

children the challenge was how do you

year the 12 districts of Panem
she'll offer up a tribute one young man
and woman between the ages of 12 and 18
to be trained in the art of survival and
to be prepared to fight to the death if
this movie is as big of a hit as they
think it's going to be it's going to
have ramifications for how Hollywood

Palin the president of marketing
alliance gate when you do something

that one way to think about how they're
approaching this is to think of it as an

engaging fans you're trying to set
little fires at the beginning of the

emerging with the box office inferno so
one component of the campaign was
registering people as citizens of this

now you can actually do it every day
they want people feeling invested in
